title: Riot, you need to spend some serious effort/money cleaning up the community.
body:
It's bad.  Really bad.   I know they like to say it is improving and that they are doing stuff, but it's not enough, and since I started playing years ago it's only gotten worse.  People don't fear any repercussions on here.  They do and say whatever they feel like, and laugh off the idea of getting reported.  They have been trained by a community that basically has been allowed to be this way by Riot.  If you start 2 week banning every single troll, I guarantee you this place would start to improve, but you won't even do that.  Why?

What you have been doing for the last 3 years hasn't even been enough to counteract how much toxicity spreads itself naturally when it's unpunished.  If you don't change something seriously impactful about how you police things, it's not going to start improving.  It's gotten so common that you can't even really play ranked and expect to get a real game.  If people lose nearly every game with a troll on the team, and win nearly every game without one, all the rank seems to indicate is teammate luck.  Is that what you really want?

I apologize for the incompleteness of my data. I was trying not to data-dump, because I have a bad habit of going overboard with that. The full discussion in that part of the talk was about this very concept, actually. To give more clarity, allow me to give you the full data they offered:

Behavioral Profile Representation (by type of Player) - aka, how many players fall into which category:
**Toxic** - 1%
**Bad** - 7%
**Neutral** - 14%
**Good** - 78%

Toxicity Representation (by type of Player) - aka, how much toxicity comes from which category of players:
**Toxic** - 5%
**Bad** - 8%
**Neutral** - 10%
**Good** - 77%

[This link](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nbYQ0AVVBGU&feature=youtu.be&t=289) should skip you to about the 5-minute mark, where Lyte discusses these numbers.

To be clear about what those numbers mean, Lyte is outright **admitting** that the vast majority of the toxicity we see in the game comes from players who qualify as "positive." The point, however, is that those players are not **consistently** toxic. It's not a regular thing for them. Rather, it's more commonly the result of a bad day, or retaliatory behavior, or whatever. However, there's rather a lot of them, so in conglomerate, they can create a **lot** of bad experiences.

> Try playing ranked and tell me there are only 8% problem players. 

Keep in mind that if 8% of players are problematic, then - statistically speaking - you'll see one a little less than every other game. If we're looking only at players on your team, you'll average one every 3-4 games.
